The '''UK Social Centre Network''' is a grass roots initiative to establish a [[Social network|network]] between self identified radical independent community [[social centres]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. There is no single policy statement but a general desire to improve communication and co-operation between the growing number of autonomous spaces ''"to share resources, [[idea]]s and [[information]]"''.<ref>[http://www.londonarc.org/social_centre_network.html LARC website] on Social Centre Network</ref>
Self selected participants draw a clear distinction between their radical autonomous spaces on one side and the state or large [[NGO]] [[Sponsor (commercial)|sponsored]] community centres on the other. While there has been something of a [[tradition]] of social spaces in occupied buildings (also known as [[squatting]]), recent years have seen an upsurge in the creation of social centres in rented or purchased buildings. The network of social centres in the UK is very much in its infancy compared to some other places in Europe such as Holland, Italy and Spain, although it can trace its roots back to the autonomy clubs of the 1980s such as [[Centro Iberico]], [[Wapping Autonomy Centre]] and the still extant [[1 in 12 Club]] in Bradford.<ref>[http://www.uncarved.org/music/apunk/autcent.html 'Autonomy Centres, Riots and the Big Rammy' in SMILE Magazine issue 12, 1994]</ref>
In 2008, the fledgling network was profiled in the pamphlet 'What's This Place?' which was produced as part of the academic project Autonomous Geographies (funded by the [[ESRC]]).<ref>[http://socialcentrestories.wordpress.com/about/ Stories from radical social centres in the UK and Ireland]</ref>

==Occasional/Evicted Social Centres==
As well as the social centres listed above, there are some projects which are no longer in existence. The [[The Forest (social centre)|Forest]] social centre and arts space in Edinburgh did not have its lease renewed. The Basement in Manchester was forced to close after fire damage from a nearby building.<ref>[http://thebasement.clearerchannel.org/new/?q=node/9 'NEWS UPDATE - a longer closure than expected']</ref> The [http://www.thecommonplace.org.uk/ Common Place] in Leeds closed down, but Wharf Chambers has started up in the same location.
Other projects such as [http://www.glasgowsocialcentre.org.uk/ Glasgow] and [http://birminghamsocialcentre.wordpress.com/ Birmingham] are actively looking for premises.
Many squatted projects have been evicted, such as the [[Bank of Ideas]], [[RampART]], [http://peckham.squat.net Peckham], Offmarket, Ratstar and the [http://reallyfreeschool.org/ Really Free School] all in London, the Free [http://freefactory.wordpress.com/ Factory] in Bristol, [http://plebscollege.wordpress.com/ Pleb's College] in Oxford, [http://www.facebook.com/#!/CwtchCommunityCentre Cwtch Community Centre] in Swansea, the [http://thepad.wordpress.com Peoples Autonomous Destination (PAD)] in Cardiff, [[Justice not crisis|Justice not Crisis]] in Birmingham, [http://www.matilda.aktivix.org/ Matilda] in Sheffield and the [http://millroadsocialcentre.wordpress.com Mill Road Social Centre] in Cambridge * There are some groups which choose to do temporary squatted events lasting a fixed time. Such groups may exist for years, such as A-Spire (Leeds), Wildcats (Brighton) or the [http://okcafe.wordpress.com/ OKasional Cafe] (Manchester), which last occupied the Gamecock pub in Hulme from February 25 to March 18, 2012.<ref>[http://okcafe.wordpress.com/2012/02/29/ok-cafe/ 'OK cafe']</ref>
